prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friend and housemates hen party?
I live with my best friend (let’s call her Stephanie) and her now fiancé (I’ll call him dave) , I pay rent for a room in the house they own together. Both enjoy having me there and in general the arrangement works out well.

They both earn more than 3 x what I do, if this matters.

They got engaged in July and I was asked to be a bridesmaid. I was very excited, and as this is my best friend of ten ish years I couldn’t imagine not being a part of their wedding. The groom and I are also good friends due to being housemates, we are almost like a little family.

I do not like Stephanie’s friends. They are mean and shallow and materialistic and when I hang out with them I feel bad. I have a history of mental health issues if this matters - a big part of my road to recovery was understanding when I hung out with certain people, I would feel bad afterwards. My mental health has greatly improved since I stopped hanging out with this group of girls three or so years ago. I kept the friendships that didn’t make me feel bad - such as Stephanie.

I enthusiastically agreed the hen do would be great and not to worry about me not liking the other girls going - I could be civil for a few days to celebrate my best friends wedding.

Stephanie’s sister and some of the girls going organised the hen do in secret, wanting Stephanie to be surprised. Three days ago I received a text from this group asking for £350 by Saturday (tomorrow) - and that if I couldn’t afford it Stephanie’s mother would pay my share and I could pay her back £60 a month. The hen do will be a holiday to The south of france for four days, staying in a luxury villa/mansion, with a wine tour, a night out and a dinner. The £350 only covers flights and accommodation and will be in June next year.

I do not have £350, I do not have £60 a month spare. I am on a debt management plan and my car broke two months ago, meaning I had to borrow money from an uncle and agree to pay him back £55 a month for three years. This was already a financial stress to me as I try to pay off my debt. I have been paying it off for three years and would have been debt free in a years time, but will be paying my uncle back for some years now. I don’t buy clothes, I don’t go out for dinners, I don’t get my hair and nails done. I am sensible with my money.

I approached Stephanie and Dave (he just happened to be there) - I said I was embarrassed about being offered to pay her mother back as they obviously know I can’t afford the hen do, and that I just didn’t know how I was going to afford to go.

Dave said it was disgusting of any friend, especially a bridesmaid, not to go to a hen party. He said he would go into debt or borrow money or “sell a limb” to be there for a friend. Stephanie said I was “being negative” that I would “upset her mum who offered to pay to be nice” and that I’m “ruining something she has dreamed of since she was a little girl”


I laid awake that night for hours trying to think of what I could sacrifice so that I will have an extra £60 a month for this hen do. I feel awkward and uncomfortable living with people who want me to go into debt for their benefit, but can’t find anywhere else to live that I can afford, though I’ll keep looking. My anxiety is through the roof at the concept I’ll be in more debt if I go.

AITA if I say I just can’t afford it and I’m not going? Even though they let me live in their home and have offered me a payment plan? I don’t want to hurt my finances but I don’t want to be an ungrateful cow of a friend. I was expecting the whole thing to cost around £200, which I probably could have squeezed. reddit, be brutal. Am I a tight fisted ungrateful asshole here?? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves not being able to afford a hen party for their best friend despite being asked to be a bridesmaid.

First, I need to consider the main points. The author is a housemate and best friend of Stephanie, who's getting married. The hen party is expensive, and the author can't afford it. They mentioned financial constraints, being on a debt management plan, a broken car leading to more debt, and not having the extra £60 a month. The friends offered a payment plan via Stephanie's mom, but the author feels pressured and might go into more debt. 

The key factors here are financial capability versus emotional/relationship expectations. The author clearly communicated their inability to afford the hen do, both upfront and when approached. They’re in a position of financial instability and are trying to manage their debts responsibly. The friends and the groom (Dave) reacted negatively, suggesting that not going is unacceptable, which adds stress on the author.

The author's mental health history and the fact that Stephanie's friends have caused them anxiety in the past are also important. They had already made the decision to avoid those people because it affected their mental health. The hen party is a group event with those friends, so attending could trigger their anxiety again.

Financial pressure in friendships is a tricky area. While being a bridesmaid is a significant role, it's also expected that the friends can manage the expenses. Expecting someone with existing financial struggles to take on more debt could be seen as unreasonable. The author isn't refusing because they don't care; they genuinely can't afford it. Their decision is based on their own financial stability and mental health, which are valid reasons.

Comparing the author's situation to the financial status of Stephanie and Dave (who earn three times as much) might highlight that the author isn't in a position to take on additional expenses. The friends' reaction, calling the author negative and ungrateful, doesn't address the actual financial reality. The payment plan offered by Stephanie's mom is well-intentioned but might not consider the author's ability to repay.

In terms of moral responsibility, the author isn't being ungrateful by not attending due to financial constraints. They have already contributed by being a bridesmaid, which is a significant role. The hen party is an additional event where the author's presence isn't mandatory for the wedding itself. The stress of attending might also harm their mental health, which is a valid concern given their history.

The broader question is whether friends can expect financial commitments from others, especially when those others are in a less stable financial position. The author's decision to prioritize their own financial and mental well-being is a responsible choice. They are not avoiding the situation entirely but are being honest about their limitations. The friends' insistence on attending might not consider the author's circumstances, leading to a conflict between expectations and reality.

In conclusion, the author isn't in the wrong. They communicated their situation clearly, are managing their finances responsibly, and have valid reasons related to their mental health and existing debts. The pressure from the friends to attend despite these factors is the real issue here. The answer should reflect that the author is not at fault.
